channel.title: The Christian Science Monitor | USA
channel.description: US national news from The Christian Science Monitor.
channel.copyright: Christian Science Monitor. All rights reserved.

item.title: A landmark settlement protecting children at the border is set to roll back
item.description: For 27 years, the landmark Flores agreement has curbed the mistreatment of child migrants traveling alone. The Biden administration, tackling heavier immigration enforcement, is now seeking to undo parts of the mandate.
item.dc:creator: Elliot Spagat

item.title: This retired Marine pilot aims to be the role model she never had in Afghanistan
item.description: Retired Marine helicopter pilot Alexis Federico is helping an aviation museum take flight in Orange County, California. She hopes it inspires interest in STEM careers.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Langhorne

item.title: College class of 2024: Shaped by crisis, seeking community
item.description: From pandemic to protests, these college seniors have faced unusual challenges. Many long for community – and have learned something about building it.
item.dc:creator: Simon Montlake
Leonardo Bevilacqua
Jasper Davidoff
Ali Martin

item.title: Trump on trial: What to know as case moves toward pivotal witness
item.description: Donald Trump’s hush money trial has seen dramatic testimony this week. But the most confrontational and legally important moment may be yet to come.
item.dc:creator: Peter Grier

item.title: Israel arms shipment on hold as US weighs new accountability
item.description: America’s role as a major backer of Israel’s military is coming under rare, rising scrutiny due to the war in Gaza. Our charts put the debate in context.
item.dc:creator: Erika Page
Jacob Turcotte

item.title: Colorado has a history of mass shootings. But Democrats nixed recent gun control bill.
item.description: Colorado has a checkered past when it comes to guns. Democrats recently joined Republicans in the state house to defeat a semi-automatic weapons ban to find a solution that satisfies both the state’s hunters and those affected by mass shootings.
item.dc:creator: Jesse Bedayn

item.title: Columbia Law grads lost commencement. And clerkships, as judges boycott alums.
item.description: Federal clerkships are prestigious and hard to secure positions for many law school graduates. But those few spots may diminish even further for Columbia Law graduates after some conservative judges announced a boycott on hiring them.
item.dc:creator: Nate Raymond and Karen Sloan

item.title: Trump vows to fire bureaucrats. Here’s why Biden is trying to stop him.
item.description: Americans have declining confidence in the civil service. The two presidential front-runners disagree on whether these workers are nonpartisan.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Babcock
Sophie Hills

item.title: Teacher apprentice programs are growing. Nevada offers a model.
item.description: One obstacle keeping people from careers in teaching is the cost of training. Enter apprenticeship programs.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Valley

item.title: By 2025, colleges could pay their top athletes directly – but what would be fair?
item.description: Nearly three years after name, image, likeness laws changed amateur college sports, an antitrust lawsuit against the NCAA wants to ensure more money ends up in the pockets of student athletes.
item.dc:creator: Ralph D. Russo

item.title: Federal funds helped millions get online. As they expire, cities face a new digital gap.
item.description: The Affordable Connectivity Program provides internet access to 23 million people – a significant plank of the U.S. social safety net. But funding will likely run out in the coming weeks.
item.dc:creator: Carey L. Biron

item.title: Teachers at a Florida school were burned out. Then they were given the freedom to be creative.
item.description: A Florida high school in Boca Raton is experimenting with letting teachers design their own curriculums and courses. Inspired by the creativity of faculty, students are designing apps and diving head first into experiential education.
item.dc:creator: Terry Spencer

item.title: Facebook ads helped Trump win in 2016. AI might help him in 2024.
item.description: Donald Trump’s 2024 presidential campaign is using artificial intelligence to parse tons of data and find persuadable voters with the help of Brad Parscale’s AI company. Mr. Parscale helped propel Mr. Trump to the White House with Facebook ads in 2016.
item.dc:creator: Alan Suderman and Garance Burke

item.title: Why Dallas wants police to adopt a ‘light footprint’ while fighting crime
item.description: Police tactics in high-crime neighborhoods have long caused controversy. Texas has a plan to change that with community help and “light footprint” policing.
item.dc:creator: Henry Gass
Riley Robinson

item.title: These Republicans want to restore trust in elections. It’s ‘the right thing to do.’
item.description: A group of Republican lawmakers has formed a coalition to combat election misinformation distrust. They aim to safeguard democracy.
item.dc:creator: Christina A. Cassidy

item.title: Why 'two Montana guys' are duking it out in the Senate
item.description: Sen. Steve Daines of Montana, chair of the Republicans' Senate campaign committee, told reporters at a Monitor Breakfast that he and the state’s other senator, Jon Tester, "get along just fine." So why is one trying to get the other fired?
item.dc:creator: Linda Feldmann

item.title: Trust in the media has tanked. Are we entering a ‘post-news’ era?
item.description: Declining trust in news media is partly about navigating a tsunami of digital content. Do people want unbiased news? How do they judge quality?
item.dc:creator: Simon Montlake

item.title: In deterrence we trust? Cold War nuclear questions make a comeback.
item.description: The risks of nuclear weapons have reappeared in global headlines. Containing those risks may hinge on communication as well as a “peace through strength” tradition.
item.dc:creator: Anna Mulrine Grobe
Sarah Matusek

item.title: Will young voters ditch Biden over Israel? For most, it’s not a priority.
item.description: Despite students clashing with authorities on campuses nationwide, most young people are far more focused on the economy than on the Mideast.
item.dc:creator: Story Hinckley

item.title: Senate map favors the GOP. But Steve Daines won’t predict a ‘red wave.’
item.description: At a Monitor Breakfast with reporters, the chair of the National Republican Senatorial Committee kept expectations in check.
item.dc:creator: Linda Feldmann
